Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} + p(x) \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial x} = 0 \\), where \\( p(x) \\) is a position-dependent velocity field. We analyze the impact of applying a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) to the function \\( u(x, t) \\) at a specific time.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), an additional transformation \\( \\mathcal{G} \\), such as a convolution with a Gaussian kernel, is applied as an intervention, will the Fourier transform of \\( u(x, t) \\) for \\( t > t_1 \\) depend only on the initial PDE and not on the actions of \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) or \\( \\mathcal{G} \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform will reflect both the effects of the initial evolution due to the PDE and the convolution intervention. As \\( \\mathcal{G} \\) can significantly alter the energy distribution across the Fourier modes, its effect cannot be isolated from that resulting from the initial PDE.
